Annual Output Results
Output Indicator

description.narrative:
Revised indicators for period 2016-2019 1. At least one policy review document adopted until the end of the project duration. 2. Updated Biomass related REAP of BiH and adopted for use in practice until January 2018. 3. Identification, quantification and mapping of biomass exploitation in BiH developed until December 2018 4. Forest governance mechanisms developed to support best practices (forestry practices, BAT and operational methods) and recommendations to increase utilization and quality of wood biomass . 5. At least three RES infrastructure projects implemented until the end of 2018, at least another 6 RES infrastructure projects implemented based on newly developed financial schemes until 2020.
Indicators for period 2009-2015 1. no. of schools with biomass boilers totalling 5200 tCO2e in direct emissions reductions 2. no. of regions where business model has been replicated 3. amount of sustainably sourced biomass fuelwood supplied at competitive price 4. reduction of perceptions of fuel supply risk based on consumer confidence survey 5. percentage increase in biomass energy awareness and capacity in project area

comment.narrative:
Revised baseline for 2016-2019 period: 1. No policy review documents related to wood biomass 2. REAP of BiH does not include specific wood biomass segments and targets 3. No exact data on biomass exploitation in BiH 4. No forest governance mechanisms in place to directly support utilization and quality of wood biomass . 5. Zero infrastructure projects
Baseline for 2009-2015 period 1. (0) zero schools with biomass boilers 2. (0) zero regions where business model has been replicated 3. (0) amount of sustainably sourced – certified biomass fuelwood supply 4. (0) perceptions of fuel supply risk not recorded-no consumer confidence survey 5. (0) no impact surveys on awareness, perceptions and capacity of biomass energy

1. Prepare Terms of Reference for National consultant for identification of policy gaps within the energy and forestry sectors in segment of wood biomass 2. Held initial meetings with relevant ministries and agencies and representatives of international agencies to agree on approach in revision of Renewable Energy Action Plans of BiH 3. Organize initial meetings to agree on joint approach of internatonal agencies for mapping biomass potentials in BiH 4. Zero (0) forest governance mechanisms developed to support best practices (forestry practices, BAT and operational methods). 5. Zero (0) RES infrastructure projects implemented.

1. Prepare Study on identification of policy gaps within the energy and forestry sectors in segment of wood biomass in Bosnia and Herzegovina 2. Organize at least 2 consultation meetings in cooperation with USAID EIA and GIZ (under activities of Bioenergy Joint Program) with representatives of relevant ministries and agencies from forestry and energetic sectors for identification of wood biomass-related issues that should be upgraded within existing Renewable Energy Action Plans (REAPs) of BiH 3. Prepare Report on analysis of wood biomass quality situation in B&H's market at initial phase of the Project; Prepare Methodology for assessment of biomass potentials in Bosnia and Herzegovina; Collect existing information on wood biomass potentials in BiH 4. Zero (0) forest governance mechanisms developed to support best practices (forestry practices, BAT and operational methods) and recommendations to increase utilization and quality of wood biomass 5. Conduct preparatory activities with 4 selected public buildings in BiH to implement RES infrastructure projects

comment.narrative: 1. 2 Water utility companies identified to test the Tariff setting methodology for water supply and wastewater 2. At least 4 workshops held for water utility companies on the subject of Tariff setting methodology for water supply and wastewater 3. At least 1 workshop held for Water Utility Association on the subject of Tariff setting methodology for water supply and wastewater

1. Two water utility companies have been testing the Tariff setting methodology for water supply and wastewater since October 2016. Those are Tesanj in Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina and Teslic in Republika Srpska, 2. 4 workshops held for water utility companies on the subject of Tariff setting methodology for water supply and wastewater in following locations: Sarajevo, Mostar, Doboj and Banja Luka. Total number of participants 140. 3. 1 workshop held for Water Utility Association on the subject of Tariff setting methodology for water supply and wastewater on their meeting of General Assembly with 70 participants.

1. 2 Water utility companies finalize testing of the Tariff setting methodology for water supply and wastewater. 2. At least 4 workshops held on the subject of Tariff setting methodology for water supply and wastewater for municipalities or Associations of municipalities and cities of federation of BIH and Republika Srpska, school children at 8th grade and NGOs. 3. Final conference held for the water governance stakeholders and beneficiaries.

1. 2 Water Utility Companies in Teslic and Tesanj finalized testing of the Tariff Setting Methodology for water supply and wastewater. 2. 12 workshops held on the subject of Tariff setting methodology for water supply and wastewater for: mayors, Associations of Municipalities and Cities of Federation of BIH and Republika Srpska; school children at 8th grade; NGOs; Cantons; water sector actors (RenExpo, World Water Day). 3. 0 Final conference for the water governance stakeholders and beneficiaries held, postponed into 2018.

1. One new governmental FLA Agency set up at the BiH level, including infrastructural and capacity building upgrades. 2. description.narrative: The armed violence prevention mechanisms instituted in Bosnia and Herzegovina.

comment.narrative: The armed violence prevention has not yet been applied as an operational concept in BiH. Although different components of armed violence prevention are being addressed as distinct, human security challenges, a comprehensive, multi-sectoral, approach to preventing armed violence has not yet been pursued by the authorities.

1. UNDP supported the revision of the 2009-2019 National Mine Action Strategy through organization of National Mine Action Strategic Planning and Prioritisation Workshop held from 7-11 November 2016 in Sarajevo. 2. UNDP provided technical advice in the development of Land Release mine action standard. In 2016, BiH adopted a new mine action standard on Land Release Procedures which are incorporated in the revised draft of 2009-2019 National Mine Action Strategy. 3. 0 training were held due to lack of funds and subsequent delays in implementation of envisaged project activities.

description.narrative: Social Protection, Land Housing and Community Amenities - disaster prevention and preparedness

title.narrative: Activity web page
Annual Output Results
Output Indicator

description.narrative: 1. Dialogue and Peacebuilding Platform developed. 2. % of population that benefited from improved dialogue and enhanced appreciation of diversity in the targeted areas across the country. 3. Number of articles/stories positively depicting peacebuilding, tolerance, multiculturalism and non-violent conflict resolution in select media outlets. 4. Strengthened youth participation in policy development and governmental initiatives. 5. Nation-wide youth network established dedicated to intercultural understanding and dialogue. 6. Perceptions of youth that they have no or little influence on important decisions.

comment.narrative: 1. No Dialogue Platform. 2. TBD in 2014 by baseline assessments of current state of play regarding dialogue and respect of diversity. 3. Number captured through baseline analysis at the start of the project. 4. Assessment of existing youth participatory mechanisms. 5. No dedicated youth network. 6. Perception recorded in 2008 and 2012: All youth responses (%): - At work, in school or college 80% (2008), 88% (2012); - In the family or household 61% (2008), 70% (2012); - In the local community 89% (2008), 97% (2012); - In political organisations or NGOs 90% (2008), 99% (2012); - Amongst peers and friends 66% (2008), 80% (2012).

1. All elements of the dialogue platform functioning. 2. 20% of population improved dialogue and mutual understanding through Grants Facility awarded community projects. 3. Number increased by at least 10 % by the end of the project. 4. At least 3 sessions/conferences organized through platform for the duration of the programme; establish new or strengthen existing youth participation mechanisms/channels with the government. 5. Network members from all parts of the country, at least 3 initiatives instigated by the network for duration of the project. 6. Perception At work, in school or college 78% - In the family or household 60% - In the local community 87% - In political organisations or NGOs 90% - Amongst peers and friends 70%.

1. Platform Declaration signed by the BiH Presidency, setting the basis for organization of three Dialogue Platform Conference. Conferences have an evolving nature with topics from previous ones discussed further. To date, over 50 recommendations were made at the Conferences. 2. Target reached. In total, it is estimated that 1,138,084 persons or more than 30% of the population in Bosnia and Herzegovina were engaged via various Grant Facility, outreach, communications and advocacy activities. 3. Target reached. Analysis of January- April 2014 when compared to the same period in 2016 show a 309% increase. 2014: (jan-apr) = 226. 2016: (jan-apr) = 700 4. Target reached. 3 Conferences organized. Additional series of 4 regional and 1 joint youth forums organized, and capacity of NGOs and government officials (Youth Officers) from all levels developed. At the end of project these total to 18 Youth Forums gathering 500 youth from across the country. 5. Target reached. Nationwide youth network emerged from youth fora, grant applicants and dialogue platform. 7 Projects brought members from all parts of the country. Network members maintain contact via closed DFF Facebook group. 6. Perceptions of youth have not changed significantly from 2012 when looking at the general population survey. Voices of Youth Survey in 2016 indicated the following: 92 % compared to B 2012 88% 68 % compared to B 2012 70% 99 % compared to B 2012 97% 99 % compared to B 2012 99% 79 % compared to B 2012 80%
Preparation of UNDP Concept Note for Phase 2 of DFF Project upon consultations with relevant donors and potential project beneficiaries.

title.narrative: Activity web page
Annual Output Results
Output Indicator

description.narrative: 1. TNC (Third National Communications) submitted to UNFCCC (United Nations Framework Convention for Climate Change) 2. - The greenhouse gases (GHG) inventory capacity for data collection and analysis process maintained and strengthened - The greenhouse gases (GHG) inventory for years 2001-2009 and 2012-2013 completed 3. - Strengthened Vulnerability and Adaptation (V&A) Team - Updated and strengthened chapter on Vulnerability and Adaptation (V&A) 4. - Updated and strengthened chapter on Mitigation - Registration of BiH National Appropriate Mitigation actions (NAMAs) enabled 5. - Updated account of National Circumstances prepared and capacity to collect and manage information strengthened - Technology Needs Assessment completed - TNC (Third National Communication) prepared, translated and edited, submitted and disseminated

comment.narrative: 1. BiH submitted its Second National Communication (SNC) to UNFCCC (United Nations Framework Convention for Climate Change) Secretariat in Nov 2013 2. - Inventory for the period 1990-2001 carried out by independent consultants - Inventory for 2010-2011 in progress - Not all emissions from energy, industrial and waste sectors covered - Several gases not measured - Need for revision of coal emission factors 3. - Set of environmental indicators not established in BiH - Lack of data on flood and draught - Discussion of vulnerability and impacts in the SNC (Second National Communications) is primarily qualitative in nature - No studies on climate change (CC) impact in tourism and health sectors 4. - Business as Usual scenario and two mitigation scenarios till 2025 developed under SNC (Second National Communications) project - No National Appropriate Mitigation actions (NAMA) approving authority established for BiH - No NAMA (National Appropriate Mitigation actions) created for BiH 5. - National Communication (NC) described in SNC (Second National Communications), but information on technology, finance and capacity needs, require further elaboration - No Technology Needs Assessment (TNA) undertaken in BiH

Development of 8 BiH NAMA (National Appropriate Mitigation Actions) proposals 5. Draft 2014 inventory conducted and Second Biennial Update Report prepared for BiH

description.narrative:
Project Main Phase indicators: 1. # of partner LGs where the LG council, the mayor and the administration jointly apply operational and accountable municipal performance management systems. 2. % realization of annual implementation plans of local development strategies of partner LGs. 3. # of citizens’ recommendations/suggestions voiced through public consultation process which were considered and addressed annually by LGs and MCs. 4. Increase of % of households in target localities with access to controlled water supply services and/or wastewater services. 5. Level of citizens’ satisfaction (dis. by sex) with services & infrastructure within target localities. 6. Number of vulnerable/socially excluded citizens (dis. by sex) in target localities with access to improved services. 7. Volume of annual private sector investments (in CHF) in target localities as result of direct project interventions 8. Number of water utilities where the water tariff setting procedure enables regular network maintenance and replacements. 9. Number of improved rules and regulations at higher or local government levels addressing regulatory gaps related to local service delivery in environmental and economic sectors, in compliance with the EU relevant standards. 10. Extent to which legislative bodies at local and higher government levels exercise oversight over result-oriented regulatory framework in the environment and economic sectors. 11. Preparatory Phase baseline: - Poor quality of water management and infrastructure in local governments leads to distribution losses of up to 50 %, increasing cost of water. - Insufficient coordination between local governments, water utilities, sectoral ministries at entity and cantonal levels for the sake of better service delivery management capacity and accountability. - Despite positive experiences, including pilot “business-friendly” certification, local governments in Bosnia and Herzegovina still lack sound economic expertise and tools to engage in productive public-private dialogue and increase investment attractiveness of their localities through viable business infrastructure, support to employability and local entrepreneurship.

Baseline for Objective 1: 39,231 damaged homes in BiH.
Baseline for Objective 2: 120 educational facilities, 8 municipal buildings damaged; Recovery Needs Assessment and based on data recorded by the enterprise survey, an additional 33,500 wage workers were directly affected by the floods and are at immediate risk. Additional information received after the conclusion of the enterprise survey by the Ministry of Labour and Veterans of RS stated that approximately 20,000 jobs remain at risk in RS due to the flood.
Baseline for Objective 3: 81 affected local governments benefiting from rehabilitated public services and infrastructure Recovery Needs Assessment (2014).

Number of FLA services for CRSV victims provided in selected municipalities in BiH 3. Number of CRSV associations economically empowered and supported through targeted interventions.

comment.narrative: 1. Existing services are fragmented and lacking capacity and awareness of the needs of CRSV victims and adding an additional stigma to those who try to claim their rights. 2. FLA services not specifically designed to address the needs of CRSV victims. 3. Weak economic empowerment of CRSV victims.

1. Additional 4 Free Legal Aid and Victim Witness Support services integrated within referral mechanisms by March 2016.
2. Additional 5 CRSV cases recorded by witness/victim support services by March 2016 with gender breakdown.
3. 3 targeted schemes organized for survivors by 31 March 2016.

1. 3 FLA NGOs supported to conduct outreach and to establish informal referral mechanisms with welfare centers and other NGOs in 18 municipalities in 4 regions (Zenica-Doboj Canton, Central Bosnia canton, Doboj-Modrica region and Herzegovina region); since in central Bosnia Canton there is no FLA governmental agency nor NGO, services were provided by the FLA NGO based in Zenica.. Through mobile teams deployed in more remote areas, access to free legal aid has been extended to a total of 1945 beneficiaries (1294 women, 650 men and 69 children), and reached out to even more people through outreach activities and hotlines. At least 61 beneficiaries were CRSV survivors.
2. In 2015 5 CRSV witnesses received witness/victim support services and 7 in 2016.
3. UNDP in cooperation with UN Women established the first economic empowerment scheme in Bratunac and initiated additional two in Gorazde and Brcko in the fields of agriculture and wool waving manufacture, targeting all together more than 100 CRSV survivors, civilian victims of war and vulnerable women, and indirectly benefitting their families.

1. Development of 3 Resource Packages (RS, FBIH and BD+State) including guidelines, action plans and protocols on referrals for justice sector institutions focusing on free legal aid (FLA).
2. 4 FLA and VWS (Domaljevac, Mostar, Sarajevo and Trebinje) providers have enhanced capacities through renovation of premises, provision of IT equipment, office supplies and training.

1. 3 Resource Packages (RS, FBIH and BD+State) including guidelines, action plans and protocols on referrals for justice sector institutions focusing on free legal aid (FLA) developed.
2. 4 FLA and VWS capacities were successfully increased.

title.narrative: Climate-resilient flood mgmt

description.narrative: Technology transfer for climate resilient flood management in Vrbas River Basin will help the government of Bosnia and Herzegovina and the population of the targeted region to develop adaptive capacity and embark on climate resilient economic activities.
capital of a political entity

activity-description.narrative: Floods risks mapping and management in the Vrbas River Basin, Bosnia and Herzegovina

description.narrative: Energy - policy, planning and administration

title.narrative: Activity web page
Annual Output Results
Output Indicator

description.narrative:
Project started in 2015.
1. Number of new technologies transferred to Bosnia and Herzegovina as part of a methodology for strategic flood risk management. 2. Vrbas river basin (12% of BiH territory) covered by an automated hydrometric monitoring network for effective Flood Forecasting and Early Warning. 3. Policy environment and regulatory framework for adaptation related technology transfer established or strengthened 4. Strengthened Capacity to transfer appropriate adaptation technologies 5. Number of institutions enabled to modify risk management strategies based on introduced vulnerability, loss and damages assessment and improved hydrometric monitoring technologies 6. Number of people in target basin benefiting from flood risk management adaptation technologies, tools, and adaptation strategies, and are less exposed to flood risk 7. Availability of innovative non-structural measures introduced and implemented as part of climate adaptation strategies to provide improved resilience to communities (include agric. 8. Number of communities benefitting from introduced forecasting, early warning, response and recovery technologies to support local communities at risk of flooding

comment.narrative:
Project started in 2015.
1. 0 strategic flood risk management technologies in Bosnia and Herzegovina 2. No automatized and centralized hydrometric network in Vrbas river basin 3. No policy/regulatory framework for adaptation related technology transfer in place 4. Local professionals are unaware of adaptation technologies 5. Most of the socio-economic information required to assess flood damages, losses, exposure and vulnerability is not currently available and is not collected systematically and gender-disaggregation of data not systematically done. 6.Current approach limited of inclusion of local communities, and particularly the vulnerable groups 7.Current approach to flood risk management is structural flood protection measures and non-structural measures are not considered to be adaptive measure. 8. 0 communities benefitting from introduced forecasting, early warning, response and recovery technologies to support local communities at risk of flooding.

1. Complete topographic (LiDAR) survey for flood risk area in Vrbas River Basin. 2. Develop methodology for flood hazard ans risk mapping in Bosnia and Herzegovina. 3. Complete hydrological modelling of Vrbas River Basin. 4. Initiate development of the National Adaptation Plan for Bosnia and Herzegovina. 5. Create institutional set-up for flood forecasting and early warning system in Bosnia and Herzegovina.

1. LiDAR survey completed. 2. Methodology for flood hazard and flood risk mapping finalized and adopted by local authorities. 3. Hydrological model for Vrbas River Basin, which integrates climate change models, completed. 4. UNFCCC focal point request for UNDP assistance in developing National Adaptation Plan received. 5. Analysis of institutional responsibilities in flood forecasting and early warning system in Bosnia and Herzegovina completed and proposal for set-up in Bosnia and Herzegovina submitted to relevant institutions.

1.Develop flood hazard and risk maps for Vrbas river basin. 2.Upgrade Water Information System and enable data exchange among water agencies in Bosnia and Herzegovina. 3. At least 7 non-structural flood risk management measures implemented in municipalities in Vrbas river basin. 4. EU Flood Directive introduced into Bosnia and Herzegovina legislation. 5. Develop Participatory GIS, as a means of integrating local community information into flood risk assessment.

1. Flood hazard and risk maps developed and adopted by local authorities. 2. Water Information System upgraded and accepted by water agencies; it contains platform for data exchange. 3. Ten (10) non-structural measures implemented in municipalities in Vrbas river basin. 4. Law on Waters in Republika Srpska amended to introduce EU Flood Directive. 5. Participatory GIS developed and introduced in 13 Vrbas river basin municipalities.

description.narrative: Fostering Local Democracy in the Western Balkans: Effective Partnerships Between Local Governments and Civil Society for Improved Service Delivery (LOD PLUS)

description.narrative: 1.Number of local governments across the Western Balkan countries with strengthened partnerships with civil society via transparent and project-based CSO funding model. 2.Number of citizens within target local governments in participating Western Balkan countries who directly benefit from improved local services as a result from the Action assistance. 3.Number of local governments and CSOs outreached through a public awareness campaign in participating Western Balkans countries. 4.Number of local governments with institutionalized model of transparent and project-based funding of CSOs in the Western Balkan countries. 5. Number of CSO projects funded in all partner local governments through the competitive model addressing citizens’ needs in participating WB countries. 6.Number of CSOs within the Western Balkan countries which have improved capacities for better service delivery as a result of the Action. 7.Number of local governments who can independently apply the transparent model after completion of the Action 8.Number of regional knowledge events organized to share and facilitate exchange of experiences, ideas and good practices among participating Western Balkan countries as result of the Action. 9. Number of local governments from participating WB countries recognized as Best Practice/Model. 10.Number of unique visits/monthly on the newly-set interactive platform facilitating virtual knowledge sharing, advocacy and communications among members on dialogue between local governments and CSOs, transparency and public service delivery issues/approaches. 11.Number of knowledge products and tools designed and introduced to strengthen local participatory democracy and public services delivery as a result of the Action. 12.Number of innovative cooperation mechanisms for civic participation introduced in partner local governments as a result of the Action. 13.Number of examined and identified standards for social services delivery by CSOs.

Level of increased capacities of relevant institutional planning structures; 3. Number of citizens benefiting directly from improved local services as result of the project assistance. 7. Number of inter-municipal projects developed with the project support by mid-2015.
Municipal Training System Project indicators: 1. % of implementation of the entity Training Strategies for Local Government Employees. 2. Level of functionality of the established entity core public structures of the training system. 3. % of public financial resources allocated through various government levels enabling effective functioning of the training system for local governments in Bosnia and Herzegovina. 4. Number of designed training programmes for local governments within the training system. 5. Number of local government employees who increase their capacity through training delivered through the training system. 6. Number of local governments who undertake reform measures towards establishment /strengthening of their HRM function.

comment.narrative:
Integrated Local Development Project baseline: 1. Local and cantonal strategic planning system is not harmonized and detached from the strategic planning frameworks and operational process of higher government levels. 2. Low development planning capacities of relevant institutional stakeholders. 3. 0 4. 5 % 5. 10 % 6. 0 7. 0
Municipal Training System Project baseline: 1. 0 % (2014). 2. Low 3. 0 4. 15 training programmes 5. 1000 6. 20

1. Further support finalization of strategic planning process in 9 partner cantonal governments based on the harmonized development planning approach; 2. Support at l 2 relevant institutions at FBiH entity level in designing relevant planning by-laws. 3. Support at 1 relevant planning institutions at RS entity level in designing operational framework for short term planning. 4. Further assist relevant institutions to manage the second cycle of the 2 public financial mechanisms supporting priorities originating from local strategies. 5. Assist 40 local governments to apply an integrated local development management approach, thus contribute to more effective realization of local strategies. 6. Support implementation of inter-municipal projects.

1. 9 cantonal governments have adopted their integrated development strategies based on the harmonized development planning approach, while planning process in 1 canton is its final stage. 2. 2 institutions, namely FBiH Ministry of Justice and FBiH Development Planning Institute were assisted in initiating the process of participatory design of a by-law on planning methodology for the FBiH. 3. 1 institution, namely the RS Strategic Planning Unit, was assisted in preparing its operational framework for 2017, to enable future successful implementation of Government by-law on short-term planning in close cooperation with other ministries. finalizing the Law on Development Planning and Management in FBiH, as well as in the design of a by-law on planning methodology (ongoing). 4. 2 entity institutions, namely the RS Development and Investment Bank and the FBiH Ministry for Development, Entrepreneurship and Crafts were assisted in successful completion of the second cycle of the 2 public financial mechanisms supporting priorities originating from local strategies (24 priority projects) 5. 40 local governments were assisted in applying an integrated local development management approach, thus contribute to more effective realization of local strategies (i.e. design of annual strategy implementation plans, annual work plans of local governments departments, annual report on strategy implementation). 6. 11 partner local governments were assisted in implementing 4 inter-municipal cooperation projects, resulting in joint municipal support to agricultural production as well as joint waste disposal management.

Previous indicators: 1.Number of organized disaster risk reduction platforms organized in BiH resulting in enhanced capacities of responsible institutions from all levels of government. 2. Number of educational events aimed at increased understanding of Disaster Risk Reduction and responsibilities of different actors in this area 3. Level of Capacities and conditions under which Civil Service Protection agencies in BiH operate. 4. Number of roaming dog management plans adopted in selected municipalities in BiH.

comment.narrative:
The RRF was revised in 2016 to include following baselines: 1. 260,000 people living under significant risk of landslides 2. 280,000 people living under significant risk of landslides 3. Semi-functional DRR Platforms with no clear institutional roles, operational framework, non-consolidated structure; DRR Platforms at the local level are non-existent 4. Innovative disaster risk reduction tool is currently not existing in BiH.
1. Disaster Risk Reduction policy of BiH is decentralized to all levels of government with different government levels without clear roles and responsibilities and with limited coordination. 2. Lack of understanding of Disaster Risk Reduction and responsibilities of different actors in this area. 3. Insufficient level of equipment at disposal by Civil Service Protection agencies in BiH 4. No roaming dog management plans adopted in Lopare and Sanski Most.

comment.narrative:
1. (March 2017): Lack of FLA resource packages.
2. (March 2017): FLA providers/MoJs have no sustainable mechanism to ensure transfer of knowledge and capacities when faced with staff turnover.
3. (March 2017): MoJs and associated FLA providers face difficulties when trying to replicate knowledge with newly appointed staff, or when faced with changes in operational procedures and service provision principles.

comment.narrative: Lack of qualified labor available at the market, particulalrly for automotive industry.
